content.description: The West Buttress is a great route that follows the prominent buttress directly under the summit of Snowdon. The rock is of decent quality for the San Juans, but there is still plenty of loose stuff. The route starts off as a scramble and steepens as you get higher. Most parties will want to rope a couple hundred feet from the summit or it is possible to bypass the 4th class sections climbing through the gully just to the right of the Buttress.
content.protection: A light alpine rack with a selection of nuts and cams. A helmet is recommended.
content.location: Take the climbing trail until you are able to ascend the scree field to the base of the climb. The route follows the buttress between two gullies. Follow the Northeast Ridge Route to descend.

content.description: Scramble around a rib to the south, & ascend talus to the start of the ridge. A steep step is encountered early where the smaller west face couloir meets the ridge - bypass it to the right.
content.location: This is the right skyline of Snowdon as viewed from Andrews Lake.

climbs.name: South Rib via The Back Up Plan

content.description: This route ascends a crack up the south west face of Snowdon.  After 200 feet of 5.7ish climbing, you top out into the main south rib of Snowdon.  Continue up along the rib or traverse along the other ribs as you make your way up to the summit.  Pick your own line.  It is 4th and easy 5th but nothing harder than you choose after "the back up plan".  There is plenty of 3rd.
content.protection: Small Stoppers, a set of cams micro to #3 Camalot tops, and a 60m rope.  10-14 slings, 10 were used on the FA, be ready for run outs, but there are not many.
content.location: Starting out, the South Rib is one of the steepest ways to access  Snowdon's summit.  There is a plethora of   5th class lines up the lower band of rock that are a rope length or so.  After the first 200'+ foot initial start of "Back Up Plan" it is characteristic of the rest of the face.  Back up plan is reached by hiking slightly around the west face and cutting up the South Ridge variation couloir, it is pretty obvious.  It took the two of us about one hour and fifteen minutes to get to the climb from Andrew's Lake.

content.description: Once on the ridge, hike to the summit with some exposed scrambling. Near the top, it's easier to leave the ridge where it narrows at the top of the obvious couloir and traverse left and then up to the summit.
content.protection: Should you need to bring gear, long slings and a few medium to big pieces will suffice.
content.location: Where the Crater Lake Trail briefly tops out above Andrew's Lake, follow a faint trail to the left of the meadow northeast to the saddle and ridge betweeen point 12,628 and Snowdon.

content.description: Slippery when wet, the North Face of Snowdon ascends low angle slabs & vertical / slightly overhanging steps.
content.protection: Wired stoppers, cams, slings, and bolts.
content.location:
It is between couloir and

West Buttress

.
